5820.bart_summary: The egg-shaped gadget acts like a beacon, or booster, to help messages move around so-called wireless mesh networks more easily. It takes advantage of a feature that launched in Apple’s iOS 7 called Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) This lets you send messages and photos even when a person has no signal by creating what is called a wireless mesh network. However, there are limits to how far a message can travel - at around 200ft (61 metres) - and Greenstone has been designed to solve this.

If the user doesn't have signal on their network, the app lets them 'roam' onto another network to connect the call. 5843.bart_summary: Scientists believe the first complex conversation between humans gradually took place around 50,000 to 100,000 years ago. Much of it, they believe, still involved cavemen grunting, or hunter-gatherers mumbling and pointing, before learning to speak in a detailed way. Shigeru Miyagawa, Professor of Linguistics at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has a different theory about what created human language. He says humans combined an 'expressive' layer of language with a 'lexical' layer, as seen in monkeys who utter isolated sounds, such as alarm calls. The 'integration hypothesis' suggests that whatever first caused them, these layers of language blended rapidly.

5992.bart_summary: The European Space Agency’s Rosetta spacecraft has survived a hair-raising encounter with comet 67P. On Saturday the spacecraft dipped to within nine miles (14km) of the surface to take a closer look at the jets that are being ejected from its surface. But during the manoeuvre, Rosetta lost sense of where it was due to the amount of dust and gas and was placed into ‘safe mode’ This caused it to momentarily lose contact with Earth. Esa said it took until Monday to get the spacecraft back into 'normal’ status. The spacecraft is now performing a wide sweep around the comet.

To test the rodents’ response to rats’ pained expressions, they showed them the photos in a specially made cage. They found that rats spent less time in the room showing rodents in pain, than they did in the other compartment showing rats with neutral facial expressions. The study suggests that as well as expressing their emotional state, the pained faces of rats may have a ‘communicative function’.
